Having fully finished V Rising I can confidently say that it is one of the best open world survival craft games. From a nice blend of survival/crafting and ARPG to great atmosphere of being a vampire in a hostile world, prowling for blood (hopefully the good quality) was a blast to play.

Let's break it down briefly:

The game plays and looks amazing, I absolutely adore the art style, animations, and effects. Combine this with the smoothness of the combat, a myriad of spells and weapons to choose from and you receive an experience that can stay fresh for long hours.

A part that I wasn't so sure about at first were the building mechanics. Some trial and error and getting to know how everything works changed my mind to see it as one of the more enjoyable building systems, albeit quite simple. However, the decorating and furnishing really ties everything together nicely in the end.

But what really made me fall deep into this game was the soundtrack. Early game, wandering through the woods at night and listening to the haunting, somber, yet very soothing melodies of Farbane Nights by Migova was truly an ethereal experience. The music fits greatly with the various areas that are present in the game, satisfyingly conveying the atmosphere. Also, the fact that every zone has a day and night soundtrack works perfectly with vampire's night prowling/sun avoiding mechanics. 

Overall, V Rising is one of the best games of its kind that I've played. Having been postponing playing it for a long time I was pleasantly surprised once i finally gave it a try. In fact I was hooked almost immediately and for a quite a long time. If you like open world survival games or ARPG games then I would definitely give it a try as well. If you like both and enjoy some gothic aesthetics, this one might be a jackpot!

V Rising Game Review
(Disclaimer - This is just my opinion and may be disliked. Please know I only recommend playing the game once and seeing what it is about as it really isn't the best game out there. Also, I played the game after early access.)

(General)
1. This game is an action, role-playing, survival game. 
2. You play as a vampire trying to reign over a kingdom again.
3. You can play with up to 4 players including ourself and it is also not necessary to buy a server to host a game (you can just host from the game servers itself, etc).

(Positive)
1. The character customization has a decent amount of options and can be altered in game.
2. The armor made in game and the cosmetics unlocked in game also adds to having a decent character appearance. 
3. The vampires in game are very Bram Stoker vampires in that they have animal forms, sunlight hurts them, garlic repels them, etc.
4. The bosses you fight to complete the story have diversity, some are funny, some are cool, etc.
5. The building mechanic for the game is really good and easy so that adds to making base building fun.
6. The game has survival elememts like needing to keep your blood reserves full, base building and resource collection to further weapon, armor, etc building.
7. The graphics is well done and the game is pretty. (Big plus is that they didn't use Unreal Engine)
8. There is a lot of armor, weapon and skill (spell power) diversity making your characters versitile and unique.
9. It is worth noting that with some armor or coemstics you can semi change the colors making it feel even more unique.
10. You can make servants in the game helping with the resource collection.
11. You can get prisoners to help you not run out of blood sources, or go look for it the whole time.

(Negative)
1. It is hard to sometimes properly see the designs of bosses as they move a lot during boss fights and don't look exactly like their codex photos.
2. The farming of resources to fight bosses, etc starts to feel excessive, repitive and annoying close to the end when it starts to feel like it isn't really making too much of a difference anymore.
3. The bosses don't have distinct patterns and sometimes beating the boss is just pure luck. (Dark Souls, for example, the bosses are difficult, but the patterns are learnable and can be overcome just by how fast you grasp their concepts.)
4. Not all the weapons, armor, pendants, rings, and skills (spell power) are as great, or useful as others. (This takes away from it meaning any build can work to fight bosses and starts to put players all in the same category making it kinda useless to have other options.)
5. It feels like some aspects of the game have a lot of attention and others not so much making stuff slip by that can really add to the game. (Some examples of this: The bosses sometimes lack in concept or abilities, the armor, etc that feels like it makes little difference later on, the skills (spell power) that has some that are evidently better than others, the blood quality that also doesn't make too much of an evident difference and something as simple as words in blocks over lapping the block and looks unneat.) (For the game not being in early access especially the last example shouldn't be a thing, but is left as the devs priorities seem to be elsewhere and not for the better.)
6. DLC's mostly add cosmetics to the game and need to be bought being as-good-as a micro-transactions.
7. Armor, weapons, etc specs percentages for certain buffs don't really greatly differ from starter stuff and a lot of the time are so low that it barely feels that you have a buff.
8. Even though you have multiple forms that you can change to there is really little use for the majority of them.
9. Also, they don't really explain bosses in the codex when you track them and you can fight a boss with the same spell-power meaining they don't cancel each other out. I just find this odd.
10. Servants take quite long to return from resource hunts, and it feels like the timer only decreases when you are in game. (I haven't experienced that in game things don't continue when you are logged out for online games often, so just noting it.)
11. The Stygian Circle, Eye of Mortium and Tombs are not really useful. The map shows basically what the Eye of Mortuim shows and you can farm more stuff in the field than the Stygian Circle or Tomb offers plus it takes too long.
12. You can only have 1 coating, resistance and buff available at a time. 
13. The game doesn't show you any sign as to weather your buffs are being stacked, multiplied, decreased, etc.
14. The golden quality pendants collected from bosses close to the end of the game and head gear in the game moves to your bag and becomes unequip when you get dropped and come back. This makes it annoying to keep having to re-equip, especially the pendants while you are in combat and need it.

(I don't hate the game, but it does need work. It is, however, really not bad if you came accross it and played it once.)

Tips (This might only make sense when you play):
1. Collect a lot of all resources from early game even if it is something like plant fiber.
2. Make use of servants and prisoners. (Just make sure to keep prisoner misery levels managed and don't send servants to hunt areas higher than their capacity.)
3. Take your time with boss fights.
4. Stick to what you are comfortable.
5. Make use of Vermin nests, 1st and 2nd Tier Stygian farms (on both levels even if you are high enough to do 2nd Tier still do a bit of both), and gardening as it really does help with late game resource farming.
6. Spend the coins you get at the market places and invest in seeds especially.
7. Take the time and build at least 4 bases (the max capacity of bases buildable) well placed accross you map to make the flow of things easier as you progress as the game is rather linear.
8. Fight corrupt bosses, especially Megara, while having corrupt blood consumed as it does help to take less damage from her and people like that, but makes you take more damage against other bosses and adds.
9. Make use of holy resistance potions. (It does help.)
10. Late game, try to only use the 2nd Tier Stygian unlocked Passive Abilities.
11. Prioritize a weapon that is close and long range. (Axe, spear, scythe, etc for example.)
12. Chaos Magic and Phantom Aegis Shield in Illusion is something I would recommend.
13. Constantly make sure things are in production to assist with late game so things are always prepared.
14. Make use of fire resistance brews as I've found this element does the most damage quickly.

(Single player review)

Very fun and polished game with a good UI and decent controller support, in the survival/crafting genre that is not always a given. There is a blend of typical mechanics (crafting stations, gathering materials and climbing tiers) but also a fair share of mechanics from the vampire theme and some of them integrate very well with the rest, creating a familiar yet original experience. 

Combat starts off pretty simple but becomes increasingly more varied. You don't end up with tons of skills or abilities but rather are able to switch freely through different spell schools and weapon types that all bring something different, so there's a lot of options to choose from which is great, although once I found a comfortable set of weapons and spells I found it hard to switch to anything else.

The grid-based base building was very satisfying and with the way inventory management is done, way less of a hassle than some other games I've played. Building adequate rooms in your base will provide you with some bonuses which makes spending some time building a cozy place really rewarding, and provides another reason to decorate it as you'll be traversing and using those rooms regularly.

I found the game very well balanced when it came to how much resource I was able to hoard vs what I was required to spend to keep progressing and it created a very satisfying loop of going out to gather stuff or beat bosses and coming back to upgrade my base and process my loot. After a while, you're able to automate getting some resources through sending followers on missions. I didn't love this mechanic being based on real time (e.g. you send them on a 16-hour mission which means you're penalized for long playing sessions and overly rewarded for playing a little bit every day). In general I don't like games dictating how often and how long I should play them. Still this was only a minor part of the game, and I was able to gather myself any material I needed anyway.

The difficulty felt right throughout the game, with some challenges here and there, though I kind of hit a wall with the very final bosses and didn't feel like it was worth it for me to really try hard (as I was already maxed out on upgrades, consumables, and minor power boosts). A bit sad to not close the playthrough with a satisfying finale, but I'm okay with the idea of a tough final challenge, I'm just not up to it. Looking up strategies online, it seems multiplayer is much less of a struggle since you're able to revive each other.

All in all a very enjoyable game, the kind that makes you forget real time passing and really immerses you in the whole gothic vampire fantasy. I didn't get to experience the coop aspect of it but it seems like that would be a fun time too! (although PvP features seemed pretty intense and a big turnoff for me, but I'm sure it's configurable)

Played V Rising multiple times starting with Early Access through release.  Each addition by the devs has fleshed out the game and major QoL improvements.  Overall I highly recommend this game if you like survival games with top down combat.  This is my favorite survival game personally though Valheim is a close second.

Pros:
1) Fluid, fun combat with lots of variations from weapons & spells
2) Well designed and challenging survival mechanics (blood pool, sunlight, silver, garlic etc) that add layers of difficulty while not being obnoxious either
3) Excellent crafting system that is mostly automated with the addition of the treasury 
4) Base building that is intuitive and pretty looking
5) Great User Interface and most mechanics are well explained
6) Wonderful theme and worldbuilding
7) Can really customize your experience in world setup to adjust difficulty and grind
8) Really fun coop PvE experience that is still challenging
9) Highest difficulty (Brutal) changes more than just enemy base stats - it also gives bosses new mechanics that changes the fights
10) Can obtain followers to gather crafting materials while not playing the game

Cons
1) Solo experience can feel a bit more punishing because of the inability to get saved when downed and getting all enemy aggro.  With friends you can alternate between healing and attacking a boss (i.e. V Blood) making it way more forgiving for mistakes.
2) High skill cap means you might get stuck in progression multiple times until you get better at playing (learning boss attacks and countering with player skills) - gear/spell progression tied to beating bosses so if you get stuck on a boss you can't just skip and come back or grind up level/stats
3) Certain crafting materials can be quite the grind to acquire (highly recommend increased resource harvesting on private server settings) 

Note: I can only speak to private server PvE Solo & Team and have not played PvP or official server PvE.

V Rising offers a varied open world, filled with unique regions, diverse enemies, and plenty of places to explore. Every new area brings fresh resources, environmental themes, and opportunities to advance your castle or improve your gear.

One of the most positive surprises is the progression system: your power depends entirely on your gear, not on traditional RPG experience. This design works extremely well, making progression feel more organic and tied directly to crafting, exploration, and defeating bosses.

The bosses are a major highlight. Each one features distinct mechanics, requiring strategy and proper timing to defeat. Beating them rewards you with key items, abilities, recipes, and structures, making every victory feel meaningful.

The game also offers three difficulty levels, which you can adjust at any time, allowing players to tailor the challenge to their preferred playstyle. On top of that, there are numerous skills and ultimates that help shape your ideal build.

Another fun mechanic is the ability to unlock multiple forms, such as wolf, rat, or bat. Each form has its own purpose, making exploration faster, stealthier, or simply more stylish.

The presence of private servers and the option to play entirely in PvE was a huge plus for me. It allowed me to explore the world at my own pace without any external pressure, fully enjoying the dark atmosphere and steady progression.

For players who love building and decorating, the castle system is fantastic. Creating, expanding, and customizing your own vampiric fortress is extremely satisfying and adds even more depth to the overall experience.

Even after defeating the final boss, the game continues: the endgame revolves around grinding for ancestral weapons, upgrading gear, and improving your servantsâ€™ equipment, giving you plenty to do if you want to keep going.

Overall, V Rising delivers a rich, stylish, and immersive adventure perfect for fans of survival games, base building, and action, all wrapped in a captivating gothic vampire world.

I played on PvE servers (from EA to 1.0 - both solo, in duos and in full 4man clans) because I love the base-building and boss-hunting loop. Blood is your lifeline, used to survive, cast abilities and maintain your castle. Sunlight burns you alive! Garlic weakens you with a stacking debuff. It's awesome!!!

Unlike many survival games, V Rising puts real emphasis on combat and itâ€™s excellent. There are no traditional classes, but various blood types act as pseudo-classes: Scholar for spell damage, Warrior and Brute for melee builds and so on. Add in six magic schools, customizable abilities and weapons with unique skills and you get a level of flexibility that encourages experimentation.

Progression is centered around defeating V Blood bosses (57 in total) - each unlocking new crafting stations, gear tiers, spells and upgrades. The structure is linear but satisfying and late-game boss farming for gems, loot and books keeps the endgame loop somewhat engaging (there is definitely room for improvement).

Choosing a good location matters, especially on official servers where prime spots disappear quickly. Youâ€™ll probably relocate your castle at least once and the new castle relocation system in 1.0 makes that painless. Instead of shuttling items across the map like in early access, you now build a relocation heart and bring your entire castle with you. Itâ€™s a massive QoL upgrade.

To be fair, this is more of a neutral review, but depending on what you are looking for, it might be negative.

Let's start with the good. The idea, the visual execution of it is fantastic here, building up your castle and decorating it is a bliss, one of a kind and you could be the least creative person on the planet and still make a good looking vampire lair.

The combat. It's simple, very much in the same vein league of legends is, as far as the ability kit you are provided is. You have a handful of slots you fill with skills of your choice that you can alter and adjust with gems for them to do what you want or what the situation demands. The attack loop for most weapons is nice and chunky and the skills with said weapons are for the most part pretty darn good to use and feel impactful. There are handful of exceptions, which used to be good and then devs nuked it because PvP balance, we'll get to that.

The grind. As long as you don't mind it and are a fair enjoyer of survival games, the grind for resources here is fairly forgiving, at least as far as the basic resources go and it's kind of the point of the game, to hoard everything you find, the only drawback really is the inventory size that for the amount and variety of stuff you will grow to need feels just too small, even with the largest inventory upgrades.

The bad and the bizarre.

There is no true single player, the game forces a server no matter what your preferred play is, and if your connection is spotty, expect disconnects, which is unforgivable, it would take minimal effort to implement an offline save, but that just never happened, because... why?

The bosses can be hit or miss, which I suppose can be expected, but some of them truly suffer from some Dark Souls hitboxes and combined with this, the mobility in this game isn't really as great as you would expect it to be. And you can get stunlocked or combo'd very easily, especially with rifts, which are basically random boss encounters accompanied by trash mobs and the stuns and charms in this game are really, REALLY long.

The final rewards for elite boss kills, which will kind of connect to the final point I will make afterwards. They are awful, absolutely f***ing terrible. From the final few bosses you get special shards that are meant to be shards of absolute power. Want to know what massive, MASSIVE powers they give you as rewards for you beating the toughest of the tough bosses? They give you a couple percentage points against other vampires, as in other players and a fairly underwhelming ultimate skill, and chances are your own ultimates will be better than those at that point... Yeah... They are meant to be the reason why people would want to fight and kill each other in this game. They are abysmally bad, for them to be the "Trophy" items.

Now the bizarre

The devs' approach to this game is mindboggling. From removing sandbox options for no reason to intentionally hard steering this game into its PvP component when they can visibly see people come back and play each and every time when they release a PvE update is just... confusing... They are trying so hard to turn this into Tarkov with vampires and that's just not what people clearly come to this game for, but they are dead set in doing so. And as a result they "balance" the game for PvP, meaning they intentionally remove or balance a lot of fun components out of the game, such as the trophy items I mentioned above, because they used to be really cool and impactful and now they are just something you throw onto a pillar and leave it there and never think about it again.

TL;DR Foundations of a good game, but frustrating to interact with and bad accessibility wise

Pro:
- Variety of skills and weapons to choose from, including upgrades to said skills. This encourages playing around with builds
- A lot of content to explore, gradually unlocking more and more as you go. It keeps you engaged for quite a while. Unlocking new skills and improvements to skills also frequently makes you reevaluate and potentially adjust your build which prevents getting bored
- Fun way to unlock new things through bossfights. I'm usually enjoying pushing hard bosses to try and unlock new goodies. The fights can be reasonably challenging as well. V Rising is no dark souls, but the boss fights can take a few tries, even on normal difficulty. Which makes it all the more satisfying when you manage to kill them, especially if you're punching above your weight class and take on bosses a tier or several higher. Or in one occasion, i fought 2 bosses at the same time (probably because they were randomly in the same area), and it was one of the memorable and satisfying fights i've had because i actually managed to win. A good fight in this game is just incredibly fun!
- Many options for customizing game rules, to adjust it from PvP to PvE / solo centric, for example if certain items prevent teleporting which would be really annoying when playing solo. Very nice!
- Some limited mod support. Not great, but better than nothing

Con:
- Terrible accessibility: If you need to have no flashing lights in a game, don't play V Rising. There's a whole area of the map later with constant lightning happening. It's seriously awful. I contacted the developers about it, and got no signs of intending to add better accessibility options in the response. Come on, this is absolute basic stuff! There are no subtitles either. At least there is a screenshake option, but that's about it
- Balancing of weapons and skills feels off, some weapons feel terrible to use compared to others. same for skills. It's not much of a choice for me personally and for example i find the bow by far the best ranged weapon (of unlocked ones so far) and generally ranged weapons seem to be the go-to. which is a shame because there are so many melee weapons, and it'd be nice if it felt like a good idea to use them
- A lot of RNG (randomness) later on. For example: Endgame weapons have different ability modifications that buff a specific ability, and also attribtes which can themselves have 1 of 4 qualities. So you have to gamble to get the combination of ability mod and 2 attributes, AND also good rolls on those 2 attributes. Getting a perfect weapon is very unlikely, which means a lot of grinding. You can also find upgrade gems for skills, but they're also randomized both with their attributes and values so same issue. There are other instances of RNG too, for example unlocking random techs using scrolls, but i don't really have a problem with that specifically.
- Not enough information. There are a lot of places where the game just hints at something and you're left wondering what it really means. If you look in the tech tree, it doesn't tell you where you make a recipe for example. Or more generally, what some unlock is. I think there are also some passive abilities, but i just don't know because the game doesn't tell you. You also do not get told where to unlock things, you just have to know. There are no search functions for this either. V Rising could really profit from QoL features from the lieks of factorio: Search functions everywhere, a clear tech tree with info on where recipes get made etc etc. You shouldn't need a wiki to look up basic info on how to play the game
- Lack of options for PvE. While there are a lot of game settings available, there are still some remnants that make playing PvE / solo more annoying than they should be. It's not terrible, but not perfect
- Controls: By default, pressing the number key for the weapon you have equipped again unequips that weapon which often gets in the way. There is a setting to change it, although why is it enabled by default at all? Took me some time to even find
- lack of QoL. A lot of manual item shuffling around. You can build buildings from central storage, but you can't make recipes that way and you have to manually get the ingredients from chests and feed them into machines. You can't queue items that depend on each other either, so if you want to make an advanced item of clothing that requires a lower tier, you first have to wait before the lower tier one is finished crafting before you can queue the advanced one. Very annoying and cumbersome
- Splitting stacks defaults to 1, i think halving as default makes more sense but you can argue about that. What you can't argue about is that it's still annoying to use otherwise too, for example if you target a partial stack that you want to add a few items to, you can't do that. You have to target an empty slot, and then you can manually merge them. There is also no way to write a number, you have to use the slider and arrow keys which is just really cumbersome to use especially with a 1000 stack so the slider is very inaccurate

Overall, it's just not very good. When i started out, i was really enjoying figuring things out and doing challenging fights, but over time the cracks just start to show. Now, every time i think "Oh it could be fun to play again" i play for maybe half an hour until i realize why i stopped playing. Interacting with the game is just frustrating in so many ways, and especially after reaching the area with constant lightning (and rain, for even more visual overload) i think i'm just done. It's so close to being a pretty good game, but it would need some more serious work on UI/UX and accessibility

Might be fun with friends, but as a solo experience it leaves a lot to be desired.

Although looking promising at first, V Rising quickly turns in a dissapointing game as soon as you delve a bit deeper in the ''story'', with the first cracks showing up at soon as entering the second act.
To better discuss the issues I found with V Rising, allow me to analize the three pillars around which its gameplay revolves : Housing, Survival, Combat.

The Housing aspect of the game is by far the most refined of the three; V Rising provides all the tools to build your own castle, using a simple yet effective modular design. Additionally, the matching room/crafting station mechanic, offers a nice and fresh spin on the traditional approach for base building often seen in other titles. 

On the other hand, the survival aspect of the game is definitely lacking, pulling only the more unintresting mechanics from its genre. Mostly notably: item craft times, item durability and the good old ''hitting a node multiple times to harvest its resources''. The only saving grace in this section would be the blood mechanic; essentially a repurposed hunger meter, not only fitting for a vampire themed game, but which also doubles as an additional layer to build customization.

This leaves the combat aspect of V Rising... which in short it's a true disappointment. When designing a boss encounter there is a clear line between an honest, challenging opponent and a frustrating mess of a fight. V Rising sistematically crosses said line. 
Additionally, due to the large cast, many bosses end up feel uninteresting and underwelming, 
recycling gimmicks and mechanics like aoe spams, minion summons and visiblity reduction effects. By itself this wouldn't be an issue, if not proposed for multiple bosses in a row. 
A final but necessary note on V rising boss design is the lack of strong identity for most members of the roaster. In other words there are too missed opportunity for strong, memorable boss encounters, potentially achievable by adding a special gimmick to the fight.
A good example would be the boss that summons an iron maiden to trap the player, damaging  and isolating them from the rest of the party. Why not turn it into a double edged sword giving the players the chance to trap the boss instead? Even if it inflicted moderate to low damage, mechanichs like this would increase the engagemaent of the fight offering creative and alternative approaches. Without them, it all boils down to the same battle of attrition, especially with the increased health pools when playing in brutal difficulty.
To quickly wrap up the combat section, V rising offers a wide selection of weapons each with its own skills and attack patterns, but in later stages those with a built in dash feel decidedly favorable leaving some options behind. The spells on the other end feel a bit samey, with all magic schools offering a different flavor of the same core abilities. A more pronunced variety in the magic departement would be appreciated.

Some final considerations outside the scope of the three ''pillars'' regard the progression, the Rift Incursion and the ''story''. 
About progression, V RIsing constantly offers new tools throught the campaing while leaving some needed quality of life improvements locked behind the later stages of the game. A good example would be the bat form, unlocked only by defeating one of the last bosses. Such an emblematic vampire power would have been useful a bit earlier, especially factoring in its limitation.

Rift incursion, while quite important for the game progression, end up being just a repetitive grind. Out of the seven faction featured in the game only one appears in the event, making the grind even more repetitive.

The final nail in the coffin is the total lack of ''story'' or context outside of some boss voicelines or description, in total FromSoftware fashion. This leads to the game failing to provide a true motivation for the player actions throughout the ''story''. Why are we hunting these bosses, why are we challenging Dracula in the first place? Just for power I guess...

TLDR: cool castles, underwelming and frustrating bosses. Not recommended.

I picked this up during the 2025 Autumn sale at half price because I had reservations about whether the game would be worth the full price. I've also sunk a considerable amount of time into Valheim so I may be a bit biased as a consequence (or just tired of survival games in general), and I play single player only because in my experience multiplayer with strangers ruins games.

V Rising not a bad game. I'm mainly disappointed by a number of dev decisions which suck out the fun (pun intended) and turn the game into a slog. V Rising could be so much more fun than it currently is but unfortunately the devs appear to have subscribed to the idea that balance and grinding is more important than fun emergent gameplay. It also looks like the devs are about the release a patch; on casual inspection looks like the patch consists mostly of nerfs to existing abilities so I'm anticipating the game becoming even less enjoyable.

What I was hoping for: A game that I could play either casually to explore environments, create fun experimental builds and extensively customize my character while occasionally engaging in interesting boss fights.

What I got: A game that superficially does these things but doesn't fully deliver on any of them, and feels like a chore to play for more than 30 minutes at a time.

What they did right: The devs nailed the aesthetic. V Rising looks and feels like a game about being a vampire trying to survive in a world filled with humans and the occasional monster. The background music is sufficiently spooky without being annoying or repetitive. The artistic style is solid.

What I don't like:

1) The day/night cycle is far too short. Typically I've only just begun to explore the environment when I feel forced to rush back to my castle so that I don't accidentally get caught outside by sunlight combined with a large number of enemies and so I can free up inventory space. I feel like this is an artificial way to ensure that players don't consistently enter sections of the map that they are too weak to explore. If so, then that may be a map size issue.

2) Re-spawn is far too fast. To me it doesn't make sense that an encampment I cleared out the night before is already fully populated the following night. I realize this was done to ensure the players have regular access to necessary materials for building and crafting, but what I have found is that it causes me to repeatedly return to camps I've been to over and over again, in part because of the short day/night cycle. This gets stale fast. Maybe it makes sense to do this with multiplayer, but ... it feels bad.

3) The camera range is too limited and frequently awkward when fighting enemies who dodge past you, forcing you to rotate the camera mid-fight to continue tracking them. This combined with the rest of movement feels bad. Additionally I'm surprised that there doesn't seem to be an easy way to view the exterior and interior of your castle from the point of view of your character, or at the very least from over their shoulder. If there was more range of camera I feel as though the game would be far more immersive.

4) Unlocking new abilities or buildables feels as though it takes forever since they are locked behind the boss enemies.

5) Inventory management is a pain (this is also true in Valheim) and I keep having to add yet more storage containers to keep up. The fact that a Devourer (recycles extra unneeded gear/books into raw materials) has to be unlocked by fighting a boss is counter-intuitive to me.

6) Additional cosmetics are locked behind pricey DLC: currently the full game plus all DLC is priced at $112.44 with a 10% discount, which is insane to me. A single DLC ranges in price from $9.99 to $29.99 and appear to be nothing more than cosmetic upgrades (even the most expensive DLC is just cosmetics). This feels like the sort of tactics I'd expect from the average greedy triple-A publishing company, not an indie team. I understand that the Castlevania-themed DLC probably necessitated a financial agreement with Konami but it still feels bad and doesn't fully explain the other packages.

Probably the biggest indicator of how I feel about this game is I find myself shutting it off after a single day-night cycle because I'm not interested in going through another loop of the same grind. I have kept coming back hoping it will get better but so far that doesn't seem to be the case.

If you are interested in this game I recommend waiting for a sale; it might be better for people who enjoy multiplayer survival games but overall I'm just not impressed. Again, it's not a bad game. It's just not doing much to capture my attention for long.
